title: Photographer Tony Mangia unearths rare East Village photos from 1980s
text:
27 shares 4

A New York photographer has unearthed rare photographs of the East Village neighborhood during its infamous 1980s heyday.
Tony Mangia , who had thought the photographs had been destroyed in an attic fire at his mother's house years ago, came across the old black and white prints while he was cleaning out his apartment last year.
He said old memories came rushing back as he thumbed through the photographs, which 'represent the East Village I remember' during the early 1980s.
Tony Mangia, a New York photographer, has unearthed rare photographs of the East Village neighborhood during the 1980s. He thought the photographs had been destroyed in an attic fire at his mother's house years ago
Mangia came across the old prints in a box while he was cleaning out his apartment last year which shows life in the East Village during the early 1980s
During that time, Mangia was co-publisher of the newspaper The Other Paper which had an office located on East Fifth Street in an area that was at the time, 'flush with crime, heroin and urban decay'
During a snowy day in the 1980s, Mangia's photograph captures an image of two emergency responders providing aid to a man
During that time, Mangia was a co-publisher of The Other Paper, a paper he refers to as 'a voice of a community', namely the Lower East Side and Alphabet City, which lasted between 1980 and 1981.
The area was at the time, 'flush with crime, heroin and urban decay' and was populated by squatters, artists, 'the leftover sixties love children' and incoming punk rockers.
It was also largely populated by Puerto Rican families who moved into the area during the sixties, according to Mangia.

The area at the time was populated by squatters, artists, 'the leftover sixties love children' and incoming punk rockers, according to Mangia
Two young children are pictured as they play on top of a graffiti-covered wall, standing over two benches and a littered ground
Mangia said through the Other Paper he and his colleagues were proud to champion local causes such as crime prevention, civic groups, politics and artistic endeavors
He said most of the photographs were taken on the drug-infested streets of the communities they covered and inside punk and new-wave rock clubs that he spent time in. He said at the time, the city was more photographically interesting than it is today.
Looking at the prints, they brought memories of drug raids and overdoses, social change without social media and abandoned tenements flooding back to Mangia.
The photographs also brought back memories of the many faces he would see as he walked on the sidewalks of the Lower East Side or of the up-and-coming new waver and local legend that might have been spotted inside of nightclubs such as Max's Kansas City, Mudd Club and Danceteria.
The photographs brought back memories of the many faces he would see as he walked on the sidewalks of the Lower East Side
The prints also brought back memories of drug raids and overdoses, social change without social media and abandoned tenements flooding back to Mangia
He also remembered the up-and-coming new waver and local legend that might have been spotted inside of nightclubs such as Max's Kansas City, Mudd Club and Danceteria
Eventually, though, came in gentrification and the East Village Mangia once knew began disappearing. An abandoned lot is pictured next to an apartment building
Now, the East Village he once knew is 'long gone' but through his photographs, he said he is happy to preserve some of the area's past
Mangia said the communities that the Other Paper covered were 'virtually' ignored by the other major New York city newspapers.
He and his co-publishers, John Lesch, Gael Gibney, were proud to champion local causes such as crime prevention, civic groups, politics and artistic endeavors.
Eventually, though, came in gentrification and the East Village he once knew disappeared, which began with the opening of the first major chain store, Gap, on St. Mark's Place.
Mangia said the area was transformed with the onslaught of more franchises and real-estate brokers as rent sky-rocketed and the area 'seemed to lose its diversity, grit and personality'.
Now, the East Village he once knew is 'long gone' but through his photographs, he said he is happy to preserve some of the area's past.
